description: Test scenario for humanities dissertation with textual analysis focus

ThesisContext.title: The Rhetoric of Empire: Colonial Discourse in Victorian Travel Narratives, 1840-1900
research_questions: How did Victorian travel writers construct and legitimize colonial authority through rhetorical strategies?
What role did gender play in shaping the narrative voice and political positioning of travel accounts?
How did representations of the 'Other' evolve across the period in response to changing imperial policies?
contributions: A new theoretical framework linking discourse analysis with postcolonial critique
Close readings of understudied female travel writers challenging existing historiography
Analysis of rhetorical shifts correlated with specific colonial events (1857 Rebellion, Scramble for Africa)
Digital humanities methodology for tracking rhetorical patterns across large textual corpus

terminology_glossary.definition: The system of statements, practices, and representations through which colonial power was articulated and maintained
A deliberate approach to persuasion through language, including appeals to authority, emotion, and logic
A term from postcolonial theory describing how colonized peoples were constructed as fundamentally different from Europeans
Careful, sustained interpretation of a text attending to language, form, and meaning
The study of how history has been written and interpreted

tense_rules.results: past for historical events, present for analysis

must_include: engagement with Said, Pratt, Spivak, and other foundational theorists
must_not_include: citation style other than Chicago Notes-Bibliography
